articles.headline: Israel’s Military Inflicted a Heavy Toll. But Did It Achieve Its Aim?
articles.snippet: Israel’s military says its airstrikes killed dozens of senior Hamas operatives and destroyed critical military infrastructure. But victory is hard to measure.
articles.abstract: Israel’s military says its airstrikes killed dozens of senior Hamas operatives and destroyed critical military infrastructure. But victory is hard to measure.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEERSHEBA, Israel — At two of the main command centers of the Israeli military on Thursday night, officers leading the Gaza offensive tallied what they considered the achievements of their latest conflict with Hamas: scores of militants killed, 340 rocket launchers destroyed, 60 miles of underground tunnels collapsed.
articles.byline: By Patrick Kingsley and Ronen Bergman

articles.headline: In Antitrust Trial, Tim Cook Argues Apple Doesn’t Hurt App Makers
articles.snippet: The chief executive of Apple, which was sued by the gaming company Epic, said his company had invested heavily on security and had lowered some fees in its App Store.
articles.abstract: The chief executive of Apple, which was sued by the gaming company Epic, said his company had invested heavily on security and had lowered some fees in its App Store.
articles.lead_paragraph: Tim Cook, testifying on Friday in a trial that could undermine Apple’s efforts to fend off growing scrutiny of its power, defended his business from accusations that it hurt app makers while on the hunt to expand its profits.
articles.byline: By Jack Nicas, Erin Griffith and Kellen Browning

articles.headline: Inside the Discovery-AT&T Deal: Cute Emails, a Big Loan and Now, a Media Giant
articles.snippet: An early-morning meeting at a Greenwich Village townhouse, under the watchful eye of Steve McQueen, was part of a monthslong campaign.
articles.abstract: An early-morning meeting at a Greenwich Village townhouse, under the watchful eye of Steve McQueen, was part of a monthslong campaign.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the predawn hours of April 1, David Zaslav, the chief executive of Discovery, arrived at a rented townhouse in Manhattan’s Greenwich Village — decorated with photos of rock stars and one of the actor Steve McQueen in sunglasses holding a gun — to prepare for a meeting that would soon reverberate across the American media industry.
articles.byline: By John Koblin, Michael M. Grynbaum, Edmund Lee and Lauren Hirsch

articles.headline: After the Cease-Fire, Gaza Wakes to a Sea of Rubble
articles.snippet: In addition to relief, some residents felt a sense of déjà vu, having survived several recent wars with Israel. After each war, it takes years for Gaza to recover.
articles.abstract: In addition to relief, some residents felt a sense of déjà vu, having survived several recent wars with Israel. After each war, it takes years for Gaza to recover.
articles.lead_paragraph: GAZA CITY — As the first day of a fragile new cease-fire between Israel and Hamas drew to a close, Sami Abul Ouf stood five yards above the ground, teetering atop a dense mound of rubble in Gaza City where his sister’s home once stood.
articles.byline: By Patrick Kingsley and Iyad Abuheweila

articles.headline: Their Own Private Idaho: Five Oregon Counties Back a Plan to Secede
articles.snippet: In nonbinding elections, parts of eastern Oregon said they wanted to join Idaho. The conservative region has long felt alienated from the liberal politics of Oregon’s population centers.
articles.abstract: In nonbinding elections, parts of eastern Oregon said they wanted to join Idaho. The conservative region has long felt alienated from the liberal politics of Oregon’s population centers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Political divisions in Oregon can to a great degree be measured by a river, the Deschutes, which winds its snaky, circuitous way through the state’s midsection. The river divides the high prairies of the eastern half — agricultural and politically conservative, largely — from the wetter, woodier western half, which has long been more populated and more liberal.
articles.byline: By Kirk Johnson

articles.headline: Republicans Move to Limit a Grass-Roots Tradition of Direct Democracy
articles.snippet: Through ballot initiatives, voters in red states have defied legislators’ wishes and produced liberal outcomes in recent years. Republicans want to make the practice harder, or even eliminate it.
articles.abstract: Through ballot initiatives, voters in red states have defied legislators’ wishes and produced liberal outcomes in recent years. Republicans want to make the practice harder, or even eliminate it.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 2008, deep-blue California banned same-sex marriage. In 2018, steadfastly conservative Arkansas and Missouri increased their minimum wage. And last year, Republican-controlled Arizona and Montana legalized recreational marijuana.
articles.byline: By Reid J. Epstein and Nick Corasaniti

articles.headline: Life Under Occupation: The Misery at the Heart of the Conflict
articles.snippet: An eviction in East Jerusalem lies at the center of a conflict that led to war between Israel and Hamas. But for millions of Palestinians, the routine indignities of occupation are part of daily life.
articles.abstract: An eviction in East Jerusalem lies at the center of a conflict that led to war between Israel and Hamas. But for millions of Palestinians, the routine indignities of occupation are part of daily life.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Muhammad Sandouka built his home in the shadow of the Temple Mount before his second son, now 15, was born.
articles.byline: By David M. Halbfinger and Adam Rasgon

articles.headline: U.S. Activists Try to Halt an Australian Way of Life: Killing Kangaroos
articles.snippet: A bill in Congress aims to ban all kangaroo products from Australia, setting up a clash between two very different kinds of people on opposite ends of the earth.
articles.abstract: A bill in Congress aims to ban all kangaroo products from Australia, setting up a clash between two very different kinds of people on opposite ends of the earth.
articles.lead_paragraph: SURAT, Australia — Ian White drove slowly over the red dirt track, past wheat stubble and into the long grass, where he glimpsed a tuft of white fur moving near the woods to his left.
articles.byline: By Damien Cave and Matthew Abbott

articles.headline: ‘We Always Rise.’ A Black-Owned Bookstore Navigates the Pandemic.
articles.snippet: Source of Knowledge has been a Newark mainstay for decades. It survived the past year thanks to the generosity of its customers and an owner who provides more than just books.
articles.abstract: Source of Knowledge has been a Newark mainstay for decades. It survived the past year thanks to the generosity of its customers and an owner who provides more than just books.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEWARK — Dexter George, the owner of Source of Knowledge, a bookstore on Broad Street here, wore a tool belt as he walked through aisles dotted with djembe drums and past walls lined with Ghanaian masks. Smoke coiled upward from a bowl of burning sage.
articles.byline: By Kevin Armstrong

articles.headline: ‘You Can Feel the Tension’: A Windfall for Minority Farmers Divides Rural America
articles.snippet: A $4 billion federal fund meant to confront how racial injustice has shaped American farming has angered white farmers who say they are being unfairly excluded.
articles.abstract: A $4 billion federal fund meant to confront how racial injustice has shaped American farming has angered white farmers who say they are being unfairly excluded.
articles.lead_paragraph: LaGRANGE, Mo. — Shade Lewis had just come in from feeding his cows one sunny spring afternoon when he opened a letter that could change his life: The government was offering to pay off his $200,000 farm loan, part of a new debt relief program created by Democrats to help farmers who have endured generations of racial discrimination.
articles.byline: By Jack Healy

articles.headline: Defying Critics, Biden and the Fed Insist the Economic Recovery Is on Track
articles.snippet: Confidence from the White House runs counter to warnings from Republicans, some investors and even a few liberal economists.
articles.abstract: Confidence from the White House runs counter to warnings from Republicans, some investors and even a few liberal economists.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — McDonald’s, Chipotle and Amazon are all raising pay as companies try to fill jobs faster than they can find workers. Airplane tickets and hotel rooms are becoming more expensive as demand rebounds thanks to newly widespread vaccinations. Supply shortages are making it tougher to buy a house or a new car.
articles.byline: By Jim Tankersley and Jeanna Smialek

articles.headline: Long Slide Looms for World Population, With Sweeping Ramifications
articles.snippet: Fewer babies’ cries. More abandoned homes. Toward the middle of this century, as deaths start to exceed births, changes will come that are hard to fathom.
articles.abstract: Fewer babies’ cries. More abandoned homes. Toward the middle of this century, as deaths start to exceed births, changes will come that are hard to fathom.
articles.lead_paragraph: All over the world, countries are confronting population stagnation and a fertility bust, a dizzying reversal unmatched in recorded history that will make first-birthday parties a rarer sight than funerals, and empty homes a common eyesore.
articles.byline: By Damien Cave, Emma Bubola and Choe Sang-Hun

articles.headline: World’s Largest Long-Haul Truckmaker Sees Hydrogen-Fueled Future
articles.snippet: Electric cars get all the attention, but truckmakers are also under pressure to shift from fossil fuels to electricity.
articles.abstract: Electric cars get all the attention, but truckmakers are also under pressure to shift from fossil fuels to electricity.
articles.lead_paragraph: Carmakers have been promising to scrap the internal combustion engine, and now it’s the truckmakers’ turn. But the makers of giant 18-wheelers are taking a different route.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing

articles.headline: Belarus Forces Down Plane to Seize Dissident; Europe Sees ‘State Hijacking’
articles.snippet: The dissident, Roman Protasevich, co-founded a Telegram channel that is a popular opposition outlet in Belarus. The plane was flying from Athens to Lithuania when it was forced down.
articles.abstract: The dissident, Roman Protasevich, co-founded a Telegram channel that is a popular opposition outlet in Belarus. The plane was flying from Athens to Lithuania when it was forced down.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The strongman president of Belarus sent a fighter jet to intercept a European airliner traveling through the country’s airspace on Sunday and ordered the plane to land in the capital, Minsk, where a prominent opposition journalist aboard was then seized, provoking international outrage.
articles.byline: By Anton Troianovski and Ivan Nechepurenko

articles.headline: Before Rage Flared, a Push to Make Israel’s Mixed Towns More Jewish
articles.snippet: An eruption of Arab-Jewish violence inside Israeli cities has focused attention on a movement of religious nationalists seeking to strengthen the Jewish presence in areas with large Arab populations.
articles.abstract: An eruption of Arab-Jewish violence inside Israeli cities has focused attention on a movement of religious nationalists seeking to strengthen the Jewish presence in areas with large Arab populations.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOD, Israel — Years before the mixed Arab-Jewish city of Lod erupted in mob violence, a demographic shift had begun to take root: Hundreds of young Jews who support a religious, nationalist movement started to move into a mostly Arab neighborhood with the express aim of strengthening the Israeli city’s Jewish identity.
articles.byline: By Isabel Kershner

articles.headline: A Year After George Floyd: Pressure to Add Police Amid Rising Crime
articles.snippet: Los Angeles, like other cities across the nation, is facing a rise in gun violence. And the police budget is growing.
articles.abstract: Los Angeles, like other cities across the nation, is facing a rise in gun violence. And the police budget is growing.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Helen Jones grew up in Watts in a time of gang wars and a crack epidemic, when the police used battering rams to knock down the walls of suspected drug houses and Black people were routinely profiled or beaten by street cops.
articles.byline: By Tim Arango

articles.headline: It’s the Media’s ‘Mean-Too’ Moment. Stop Yelling and Go to Human Resources.
articles.snippet: In public radio, there is either an epidemic of bullying or an epidemic of whining, depending on whom you ask.
articles.abstract: In public radio, there is either an epidemic of bullying or an epidemic of whining, depending on whom you ask.
articles.lead_paragraph: For 20 years, the WNYC radio show “On The Media” has been the sort of place where the hosts’ on-air repartee makes it a fun listen, while their off-air screaming matches send producers diving for cover.
articles.byline: By Ben Smith

articles.headline: Why Arkansas Is a Test Case for a Post-Trump Republican Party
articles.snippet: Sarah Huckabee Sanders seems likely to bring the Trump brand to Arkansas politics in a big way. But the state is a testing ground for different possible futures for the party.
articles.abstract: Sarah Huckabee Sanders seems likely to bring the Trump brand to Arkansas politics in a big way. But the state is a testing ground for different possible futures for the party.
articles.lead_paragraph: LITTLE ROCK, Ark. — For decades, Arkansas punched above its weight in politics and business.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin

articles.headline: The Costly Pursuit of Self-Driving Cars Continues On. And On. And On.
articles.snippet: Many in Silicon Valley promised that self-driving cars would be a common sight by 2021. Now the industry is resetting expectations and settling in for years of more work.
articles.abstract: Many in Silicon Valley promised that self-driving cars would be a common sight by 2021. Now the industry is resetting expectations and settling in for years of more work.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was seven years ago when Waymo discovered that spring blossoms made its self-driving cars get twitchy on the brakes. So did soap bubbles. And road flares.
articles.byline: By Cade Metz

articles.headline: Airlines Start Skirting Belarus After It Forced Down a Plane
articles.snippet: The European Union told airlines to avoid Belarusian airspace after the country forced a commercial flight to land in order to arrest a journalist.
articles.abstract: The European Union told airlines to avoid Belarusian airspace after the country forced a commercial flight to land in order to arrest a journalist.
articles.lead_paragraph: The brazen decision by Belarus’s president this weekend to force a commercial flight to land in order to arrest a dissident journalist shows how abruptly aviation can become entangled in geopolitics, sometimes with dangerous potential consequences.
articles.byline: By Niraj Chokshi and Stanley Reed

articles.headline: A Serene Shore Resort, Except for the SpaceX ‘Ball of Fire’
articles.snippet: For years, those in a rural Texas village cherished living among nature and wildlife. Elon Musk’s SpaceX has brought new fears and the promise of an economic boost to one of America’s poorest corners.
articles.abstract: For years, those in a rural Texas village cherished living among nature and wildlife. Elon Musk’s SpaceX has brought new fears and the promise of an economic boost to one of America’s poorest corners.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOCA CHICA, Texas — The text arrived late at night: For your own safety, leave home by morning, it read. Nancy and James Crawford, no longer surprised but still unsettled, raced away in their S.U.V. after sunrise, occasionally twisting their necks to catch a glimpse of the space rocket towering behind them.
articles.byline: By Edgar Sandoval and Richard Webner
